content.text:
# Draft:List of presidential trips made by George W. Bush (2001)

This is a list of presidential trips made by George W. Bush during 2001, the first year of his presidency as the 43rd President of the United States.
This list excludes trips made within Washington, D.C., the U.S. federal capital in which the White House, the official residence and principal workplace of the president, is located. Also excluded are trips to Camp David, the country residence of the president, as well as Joint Base Andrews. International trips are included. Here are the number of visits per state or territory he traveled to:
*One: California, Connecticut, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Louisiana, Maine, Massachusetts, Nebraska, Ohio, Pennsylvania, South Carolina, Virginia, Wisconsin
*Two: Michigan, Texas
*Three: Florida
*Four: New York
International
5 trips, 11 countries
January
No trips outside of Washington, D.C.
February
{| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto"
|-

U.S. state

! width=150|Image
|-
|
|San Cristóbal
|February 16
|Met with President Vicente Fox; discussed trade, energy, migration, educational opportunities, and the battle against the illegal drug trade.
|
|-
|
|Columbus
|February 20
|Talked to an education roundtable with Laura Bush and Rosa Smith, Superintendent of the Columbus School district at Sullivant Elementary School.
|
|}
March
{| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto"
|-
! width=120|Country/
U.S. state
! width=100|Areas visited
! width=70|Dates
! width=550|Details
! width=150|Image
|-
|
|Chicago
|March 6
|Addressed questions from reporters on his Chicago visit, tax relief legislation, and Vice President Cheney in the Executive Conference Room at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange; delivered an afternoon address to the Chicago Mercantile Exchange reflecting on his activities since arriving in the city and promoting the benefits of his tax relief plan.
|
|-
|
|Panama City
|March 12
|Spoke at a Panama City Youth Activities Center, stating his administration wants to make sure service members are housed properly during their service and claims to have enough money to accomplish this goal; announced plans for the nomination of Paula J. Dobriansky as Under Secretary of State for Global Affairs and Dale Cabaniss for Chairman of the Federal Labor Relations Authority.
|
|-
|
|Boston
|March 13
|Signed a bill designating a newly built courthouse in Boston as the "John Joseph Moakley Federal Courthouse" in honor of retiring congressman Joe Moakley; met with Congress, reversing a campaign pledge to impose mandatory emission reductions on carbon dioxide on US power plants.
|
|-
|
|Kalamazoo
|March 27
|Speaking in Kalamazoo, took issue with a Democratic proposal in Congress for an immediate tax rebate, stating that the American economy needs more than a one-time tax cut.
|
|}
April
{| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto"
|-
! width=120|Country/
U.S. state
! width=100|Areas visited
! width=70|Dates
! width=550|Details
! width=150|Image
|-
|
|Quebec City
|April 20–22
|Attended the 3rd Summit of the Americas.
|
|}
May
{| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto"
|-
! width=120|Country/
U.S. state
! width=100|Areas visited
! width=70|Dates
! width=550|Details
! width=150|Image
|-
|
|Conestoga
|May 18
|Signed two executive orders, the first hastening energy projects becoming available online, and the second keeping regulators focused on the impact of energy in decision making.
|
|-
|
|Notre Dame
|May 20
|Delivered the commencement address at Notre Dame University.
|
|-
|
|New Haven
|May 21
|Delivered the commencement address at Yale University.
|
|-
|
|Sequoia National Park, Los Angeles
|May 30–31
|Gave a speech at the Giant Forest Museum in Sequoia National Park during the morning; delivered an address to the Los Angeles World Affairs Council at Century Plaza in Los Angeles during the afternoon.
|
|}
June
{| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto"
|-
! width=120|Country/
U.S. state
! width=100|Areas visited
! width=70|Dates
! width=550|Details
! width=150|Image
|-
|
|Everglades National Park
|June 4
|During an appearance at the Everglades National Park, nominated Fran Mainella to lead the National Park Service.
|
|-
|
|Unspecified farm
|June 8
|Appeared at an Iowa farm, where he insisted tax relief is impending.
|
|-
|
|Madrid
|June 12–13
|Met with King Juan Carlos I and Prime Minister José María Aznar in Spain.
|
|-
|
|Brussels
|June 13–14
|Attended NATO Summit Meeting in Belgium.
|
|-
|
|Gothenburg
|June 14–15
|Attended U.S.-EU Summit Meeting in Sweden; met with King Carl XVI Gustav.
|
|-
|
|Warsaw
|June 15–16
|State visit to Poland, met with President Aleksander Kwaśniewski and Prime Minister Jerzy Buzek, delivered a foreign policy speech at Warsaw University.
|
|-
|
|Kranj
|June 16
|Summit meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin in Slovenia.
|
|}
July
{| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto"
|-
! width=120|Country/
U.S. state
! width=100|Areas visited
! width=70|Dates
! width=550|Details
! width=150|Image
|-
|
|Kennebunkport
|July 5–9
|Visited family at Walker's Point Estate for the weekend.
|
|-
|
|Ellis Island
|July 10
|Requested a relaxed system of immigration during a speech at Ellis Island.
|
|-
|
|London, Chequers, Halton, Brize Norton
|July 18–20
|Met with Prime Minister Tony Blair and Queen Elizabeth II in the UK.
|
|-
|
|Genoa, Castel Gandolfo, Rome
|July 20–24
|Attended the 27th G8 summit in Genoa, met with Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi and President Carlo Azeglio Ciampi in Rome, audience with Pope John Paul II at Castel Gandolfo.
|
|-
|
|Camp Bondsteel
|July 24
|Addressed U.S. military personnel in Kosovo.
|
|}
August
{| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto"
|-
! width=120|Country/
U.S. state
! width=100|Areas visited
! width=70|Dates
! width=550|Details
! width=150|Image
|-
|
|Crawford, San Antonio
|August 3–September 2
|Month-long working vacation at Prairie Chapel Ranch in Crawford; gave tour of ranch on August 25; addressed the 83rd national convention of the American Legion in San Antonio on August 29, highlighting commitment to veterans' health care.
|
|}
September
{| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto"
|-
! width=120|Country/
U.S. state
! width=100|Areas visited
! width=70|Dates
! width=550|Details
! width=150|Image
|-
|
|Green Bay, Detroit
|September 3
|Spent his first Labor Day in office visiting a carpenters union local in Green Bay and joining a picnic at Teamsters headquarters in Detroit.
|
|-
|
|Jacksonville, Sarasota, Barksdale Air Force Base, Offutt Air Force Base
|September 10–11
|Visited Justina Road Elementary School in Jacksonville on September 10; visited Emma E. Booker Elementary School in Sarasota on September 11, where he learned of the terrorist attacks; traveled to Barksdale Air Force Base in Louisiana, then to Offutt Air Force Base in Nebraska before returning to Washington, D.C.
|
|-
|
|New York City
|September 14
|Viewed the damage from the September 11 attacks and addressed rescue and recovery workers at the World Trade Center site.
|
|}
October
{| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto"
|-
! width=120|Country/
U.S. state
! width=100|Areas visited
! width=70|Dates
! width=550|Details
! width=150|Image
|-
|
|Shanghai
|October 18–21
|Attended the 13th APEC summit meetings.
|
|-
|
|New York City
|October 30
|Threw out the ceremonial first pitch at Yankee Stadium for game three of the 2001 World Series.
|
|}
November
{| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto"
|-
! width=120|Country/
U.S. state
! width=100|Areas visited
! width=70|Dates
! width=550|Details
! width=150|Image
|-
|
|New York City
|November 10–11
|Addressed the United Nations General Assembly on November 10, asking for help in combating terrorism; attended the Veterans Day Prayer Breakfast at the Park Avenue Seventh Regiment Armory on November 11.
|
|}
December
{| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto"
|-
! width=120|Country/
U.S. state
! width=100|Areas visited
! width=70|Dates
! width=550|Details
! width=150|Image
|-
|
|Norfolk
|December 7
|Addressed the crew of the USS Enterprise on the 60th anniversary of the attack on Pearl Harbor.
|
|-
|
|Charleston
|December 11
|Delivered a speech at The Citadel, calling for improvements in intelligence-gathering and military readiness to combat terror.
|
|-
|
|Crawford
|December 28–31
|Spoke to reporters at his ranch on December 28, foreseeing U.S. troops staying in Afghanistan for a long period; predicted a favorable year for America on December 31 while speaking at a local store.
|
|}
